title: Shell to cut 6,500 jobs after big second quarter profits beat
text:

Thu, Jul 30, 2015, 08:46 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 44 mins Shell to cut 6,500 jobs after big second quarter profits beat By Oliver Haill | Sharecast â€“ 11 minutes ago 1,067.00 +27.0000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - As it revealed 6,500 job cuts, Royal Dutch Shell (Xetra: R6C1.DE - news ) also delivered a second-quarter profit that was well ahead of the market's expectations but warned it expected the oil price slump to "last for several years". Adjusted profits of $3.8bn from the Anglo-Dutch giant beat the consensus estimate of $3.4bn soundly and the oil major also kept its dividend steady at $0.47 for ordinary shares and $0.94 per American depositary share. 
Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) wants to further reduce 2015 capital investment to $30bn, 20% below where it stood a year ago due to its dim view of the oil price environment. Operating costs are expected to fall by $4bn, or around 10 per cent, in 2015 as part of chief executive Ben van Beurden's efficiency drive, with further reductions in operating costs expected next year. 
Shell said it expects $30bn of asset sales between 2016 and 2018, on top of a total of $20bn in disposals for 2014 and 2015 combined. 
"We have to be resilient in a world where oil prices remain low for some time, whilst keeping an eye on recovery," van Beurden said. 
"We're taking a prudent approach, pulling on powerful financial levers to manage through this downturn, always making sure we have the capacity to pay attractive dividends for shareholders." Van Beurden also gave a progress report on the proposed merger with BG Group (LSE: BG.L - news ) . 
"At the same time, we are making good progress with the recommended combination with BG, which should enhance our free cash flow, create an IOC leader in LNG and deep water innovation, and be a springboard to change Shell into a simpler and more profitable company. The regulatory filings process and integration planning are both progressing well."
